Tomato leaf late blight.name: Tomato leaf late blight
Tomato leaf late blight.description: Late blight is a destructive disease of tomato and potato caused by the water mold Phytophthora infestans. It can rapidly destroy entire crops in favorable weather conditions (cool and moist).
symptoms: Dark brown to purplish-black spots on leaves
White fuzzy growth on undersides of leaves
Rapid yellowing and death of foliage
Brown lesions on stems
Dark spots on tomato fruits

organic: Remove and destroy infected plant parts immediately
Use baking soda spray (1 tablespoon per gallon water)
Apply neem oil as preventive measure
chemical: Use metalaxyl or dimethomorph for severe infections
cultural: Improve air circulation by spacing plants properly
Water at the base, avoid overhead watering
Remove weeds that can harbor the pathogen
Stake and prune plants to improve air flow

prevention: Apply mulch to prevent soil splash onto leaves
Monitor weather conditions and apply preventive fungicides before rain
Rotate crops - don't plant tomatoes in same location for 3-4 years
Ensure good drainage in the field

Tomato Early blight leaf.name: Tomato Early blight leaf
Tomato Early blight leaf.description: Early blight is a common tomato disease caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. It affects leaves, stems, and fruits, causing yield loss if not managed properly.
symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (target-like pattern)
Yellowing of leaves around the spots
Leaf drop starting from bottom of plant
Stem lesions with dark rings
Sunken spots on fruits near the stem

organic: Use compost tea as foliar spray
cultural: Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash
Space plants adequately for air circulation
Water at base of plants, not overhead
Stake plants to keep foliage off ground

prevention: Rotate crops - avoid planting tomatoes in same spot for 3 years
Remove plant debris at end of season
Apply preventive fungicides before disease appears
Ensure adequate soil fertility, especially nitrogen

Potato leaf early blight.name: Potato leaf early blight
Potato leaf early blight.description: Early blight of potato is caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. It primarily affects older leaves and can reduce yield by causing premature defoliation.
symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves
Yellow halo around the spots
Leaves turn yellow and die from bottom up
Stem lesions near soil line
Tuber infections causing dark, sunken lesions

cultural: Hill soil around plants to protect stems
Mulch to prevent soil splash
Improve drainage in field
Space plants for good air flow

prevention: Monitor and apply fungicides before disease onset

Potato leaf late blight.name: Potato leaf late blight
Potato leaf late blight.description: Late blight is the most devastating disease of potato, historically responsible for the Irish potato famine. Can destroy entire fields within days under favorable conditions.
symptoms: Water-soaked spots on leaves that turn brown or black
White mold growth on undersides of leaves in humid conditions
Rapid browning and death of foliage
Brown rot of tubers starting from surface
Characteristic 'burnt' appearance of fields

organic: Harvest tubers as soon as possible
chemical: Use metalaxyl or mefenoxam for curative action
Use tank mixtures for broad spectrum control
cultural: Destroy volunteer potato plants
Hill soil high to protect tubers
Avoid overhead irrigation
Kill vines 2 weeks before harvest

prevention: Monitor weather and spray before rain

Corn leaf blight.name: Corn leaf blight
Corn leaf blight.description: Northern corn leaf blight is a foliar disease that can significantly reduce yield by decreasing photosynthetic area and causing premature death of leaves.
symptoms: Long, elliptical gray-green to tan lesions on leaves
Lesions may merge and cover large areas of leaf blade
Lesions start on lower leaves and progress upward
Dark gray sporulation in humid conditions
Premature death of leaves

organic: Apply compost tea to boost plant immunity
chemical: Time applications at early disease stages
cultural: Plant resistant hybrids
Ensure adequate plant spacing
Manage nitrogen levels properly
Bury crop residue by deep plowing

prevention: Monitor fields regularly for early detection

Apple Scab Leaf.name: Apple Scab Leaf
Apple Scab Leaf.description: Apple scab is one of the most serious diseases of apple trees. It affects leaves, fruit, and young twigs, causing significant economic losses.
symptoms: Olive-green to brown velvety spots on leaves
Spots turn dark brown to black as they age
Leaves may curl and fall prematurely
Scabby lesions on fruit
Cracked and deformed fruit

organic: Apply sulfur sprays starting at bud break
Use lime sulfur during dormant season
chemical: Maintain regular spray schedule during rainy periods
cultural: Prune trees for better air circulation
Rake and destroy fallen leaves in autumn
Apply mulch over fallen leaves
Space trees properly

prevention: Remove fallen leaves and fruit in autumn
Begin preventive sprays at bud break

Bell_pepper leaf spot.name: Bell_pepper leaf spot
Bell_pepper leaf spot.description: Bacterial leaf spot is a serious disease of bell peppers causing leaf drop and reduced fruit quality. Thrives in warm, humid conditions.
symptoms: Small, dark brown spots with yellow halos on leaves
Spots may merge causing large dead areas
Leaves turn yellow and drop prematurely
Raised, corky spots on fruits
Reduced fruit quality and yield

chemical: Apply copper hydroxide or copper sulfate
cultural: Remove infected plant parts immediately
Avoid overhead watering
Disinfect tools between plants
Improve air circulation
